alert.note: Alert for Central Highlands; Chuska Mountains; Eastern Lincoln County; Espanola Valley; Estancia Valley; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Lower Rio Grande Valley; Northwest Highlands; San Agustin Plains and Adjacent Lowlands; San Francisco River Valley; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southwest Chaves County; Southwest Mountains; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Upper Tularosa Valley; West Central Mountains; West Central Plateau (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 9:04AM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...WINTER TRAVEL CONDITIONS EXPECTED ACROSS WESTERN AND CENTRAL NEW MEXICO THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE EVENING... A Winter Storm Warning remains in effect from 11 AM MST through 7 AM MST Tuesday across the northern high terrain where significant snowfall accumulations can be expected, creating difficult travel conditions. While total snow amounts will be lower across western New Mexico and the central and south central mountains, minor to locally moderate travel impacts can be expected as a storm system continues to approach the region and snow levels lower. Precipitation is expected to develop across the Upper Gila region by late this morning, then spread north and east into northern and central New Mexico this afternoon and evening. Given the amount of instability in the atmosphere, there will be a threat for isolated thunderstorms this afternoon over western New Mexico. Snow levels will initially range from 6,000 to 7,500 feet then gradually lower throughout the day. As a result, thundersnow will be possibility, creating a threat for rapidly changing road conditions and reduced visibilities, particularly along U.S. Highway 60, Interstate 40 at the Continental Divide as well as U.S. Highway 550 from near Cuba to Nageezi. Any thunderstorm will also be capable of wind gusts up to 50 mph. Snow accumulations by late this evening will range from around half an inch to two inches for locales below 7,500 feet and generally two to four inches in the higher terrain. For the latest New Mexico road conditions call 511 or visit nmroads.com. Stay tuned to the latest weather forecast and statements regarding this fast moving storm at weather.gov/abq or through your preferred media outlet.
